10. If a future president gives a speech accusing Republicans of wanting to cancel the frisizhnjubs program in exchange for raising the debt ceiling, anyone expressing disagreement must face accusations of hypocrisy if they previously noted the many problems with the program.
9. If you don’t believe the federal frisizhnjubs program is a good deal, now or at any point in the future, you’re a MONSTER.

8. Having the federal government provide frisizhnjubs really is that important—so much so that logic and reason must be suspended in the perpetual defense of the sacred (but often desecrated) federal frisizhnjubs program.

7. Bottom line, public officials must never be allowed to question the ABSOLUTE sanctity of the frisizhnjubs program—and anyone who does so must be accused of wanting to steal or otherwise deprive Americans of frisizhnjubs, even if they make clear that the opposite is true.

6. The important thing is to recognize that the American people can’t possibly live without the federal frisizhnjubs program—no matter how often the government steals from it and makes a mockery of its promises.

5. The shaming is necessary even if the person criticizing the program makes clear that the government must make whole those who have paid frisizhnjubs taxes into the frisizhnjubs program for decades and relied on the promise of government-issued frisizhnjubs later in life.

4. For that matter, we should prepare to shame ANYONE in the future who might point out—after decades of abuse within the frisizhnjubs program—that the federal government is really bad at handling frisizhnjubs, and that it might be better to revisit the entire program.

3. People who raise these questions—or in any way doubt the federal government’s capacity and inclination to act in the best interests of the people when it comes to frisizhnjubs—should be shamed into the understanding that they must NEVER EXPRESS DISTRUST OF THE GOVERNMENT.

2. Others may ask “do we have any reason to worry that the government will eventually take some of the frisizhnjubs money and use it for something else, or mismanage it to the point that people will actually pay more for frisizhnjubs and get less?”

RT @SenateAgGOP 🧵/ Ranking Member @JohnBoozman  begins his opening statement by noting how farmers rely on the safety net created by commodity, crop insurance & credit programs to manage the “tremendous financial risk inherent to agriculture” that has “only increased since the last farm bill.”
“I know that if we listen to our farmers and ranchers we will find a way to provide the right tools to manage risk now and in the future.” - @JohnBoozman

RM @JohnBoozman  concludes by expressing hope that today’s hearing will help bring these issues to light, that producers will hear the assurances they deserve & that the administration & Congress understand the need to strengthen the farm safety net.

“The important thing is that we all–producers, consumers, Congress, and the administration–stand together in support of a strong and resilient safety net. The next farm bill must work for those that feed and clothe us.” - @JohnBoozman
“The farm safety net can work for all producers—large or small, organic or conventional, farms established a century ago or those just starting out.” - @JohnBoozman

“We cannot only focus on certain programs and ignore others when all farm bill programs are necessary to achieve economic sustainability for our farmers and ranchers & rural communities.” - @JohnBoozman
“Farm bill programs collectively result in public benefits across the rural and urban landscape and we owe it to all Americans to ensure the bottom does not fall out of agriculture.” - @JohnBoozman
Using corn prices as an example, @JohnBoozman  says they would have to decline by 46% before farmers would receive help—well after significant damage would have already been done.

• Farm production costs are estimated to be $460 billion this year. 
• Crop prices are likely to decline in the coming years, but prices for many of our major commodities would have to drop sharply before the current Title I Price Loss Coverage safety net would start to work.
RM @JohnBoozman  says the risk in farming has never been greater.
“However, neither the administration nor the reconciliation process have done anything to bolster the safety net.” - @JohnBoozman

“Climate change & nutrition programs have seen dramatic increases in funding while farm safety net resources have dwindled.” - @JohnBoozman  says citing quarter of a trillion in SNAP funding & $37 billion added to USDA conservation, forestry & RD programs thru reconciliation.

“A newly reinforced safety net is essential if the United States would like our farmers and ranchers to continue to produce the most abundant, most affordable, and safest food supply in the world.” - @JohnBoozman
“Our producers are one trade war, natural disaster, market downturn or geopolitical conflict away from having to sell the farm.” - @JohnBoozman

“When I meet with farmers across Arkansas, they share their hopes and fears with me. The hope is that their children will one day take over the family farm. The fear is, of course, that this will not happen, through no fault of their own.” - @JohnBoozman

“The 2023 farm bill must provide our producers with the risk management tools required to farm and ranch in this new reality. The current safety net has frayed and is in dire need of meaningful reinforcement.” - @JohnBoozman

Hayling and other activists would continue the work, as neither the Civil Rights Act nor the Governor's commission was enough to tame the prejudice in the hearts of St. Augustine's civic leaders.

#BlackHistoryMonth #SayBlack

https://accordfreedomtrail.org/hayling.html

While the chapter of King’s life in St. Augustine is not as well-known as his time in Washington, D.C., Birmingham, or Atlanta, it demonstrates not only his commitment to non-violence, but also his tenacity.

The SCLC left after the Governor of Florida set up a biracial commission to address race relations in St. Augustine, just as the Civil Rights Act was passed at the national level. In some ways King was successful; in other ways, the SCLC failed.

Hayling, King, and many others were arrested, but the activists persisted. King said, “there will be neither peace nor tranquility in this community until the righteous demands of the Negro are fully met.”

In St. Augustine, King and the SCLC preached non-violence, leading sit-ins and other actions to desegregate the city. Previously, Hayling had resigned from the NAACP for actions that were perceived as militant and violent.

On this day in 1964, civil rights leader and dentist Dr. Robert B. Hayling reached out to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. and the Southern Christian Leadership Conference (SCLC) for help in desegregating St. Augustine, Florida.

#BlackHistoryMonth #SayBlack http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FoiEJ45XoAArBOm.jpg
